What it does say is this: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof;" The first draft of the Bill of Rights was written by James Madison. The final version is significantly different from the first draft - in fact, it is stronger in the statement of religious freedom. There are two clauses - the Establishment Clause, and the Free Exercise Clause. The first prohibits government from endorsing or supporting religion, not only a single religious sect, but all religion. The second prohibits the government from outlawing or seriously burdening a person's right to worship (or not) as he chooses.

On February 25, 2004, the Supreme Court ruled in Locke v. Davey that Washington State is permitted to withhold state college scholarship funds to students studying devotional theology. The case centers on Joshua Davey, a student awarded a state-sponsored college scholarship based upon academic merit and financial need. After enrolling in school, Davey was notified that he was no longer eligible to receive his scholarship because he had chosen to major in theology. The state argued that the exclusion of theology studies from its college scholarship program was mandated by the state constitution, which prohibits public money from being used to provide any religious instruction or support any religious establishment. Davey argued that exempting theology majors from the scholarship program violated his constitutional right to freely exercise his religion.
 
 In a 7-2 decision, the Court held that the state of Washington is free to interpret its constitution's anti-establishment clause to preclude funding of religious training in a general scholarship program, and that such exclusion does not run afoul of the First Amendment's Free Exercise clause. The Court noted that many states have similar anti-establishment provisions in their state constitutions and that such provisions permit, but do not require, states to exclude religious studies from state-funded educational programs.

Also how do we know they meant both meanings of establishment?

 Because they are actually the same. What is literally stated is that Congress cannot establish a state religion, whether that is to make an already existing religion the state religion, or to invent one. The Establishment Clause has been interpreted by the Supreme Court (that is the job of the Supreme Court - to decide questions of the meaning of the Constitution) to mean that the government may not endorse or support religion. Not only is it prohibited from endorsing a particular religion, but neither may government support or endorse religion in general.
 
Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion

 No. That's the Free Exercise Clause which prevents the government from outlawing or burdening a person's pursuit of religion. This clause says that the government may not decide how anyone is to practice their religion or whether they are to practice religion.

 At the time that the Constitution was written, many of the states had an official state religion (Rhode Island never did and Virginia had disestablished theirs in 1796). They were mostly Congregationalist (Puritan) in the north and Anglican (Episcopalean) in the south. But there was still some considerable religious diversity everywhere. Much of the opposition to the Constitution came from those who were horrified at the prospect of a non-Protestant holding office. The equality of all men proclaimed in the Declaration of Independence didn't extend as far as Quakers, Catholics, or Jews for many Protestants.

Since the law in question did not interfere with the plaintif's right to practice his religion freely, it was not a violation of the Free Exercise Clause.
